metadata.case_name: Manu Bhusan Roy Pradhan v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Order of detention passed by District Magistrate, Jalpaiguri on August 21, 1971 under S.3(2) read with S.9 of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 to prevent petitioner from acting in manner prejudicial to maintenance of public order.

Ground 1: On 16-4-71 at about 20.00 hours, petitioner along with others committed murderous assault on Shri Bulo Das Gupta on road in front of Mahila Samity, Dhupguri, causing severe injuries; Das Gupta died in hospital; people terrorised, public peace disturbed.

Ground 2: On 19-7-1971 at about 19.30 hours, petitioner along with others forcibly entered Dhupguri High School and set fire to school buildings causing irreparable loss; object to cause dislocation in education system and compel closure; teachers and locals panic-stricken, public peace disturbed.
Detention order reported to State Government on August 23, 1971; approved by State Government on August 31, 1971; reported to Central Government same day.
Case placed before Advisory Board on December 9, 1971; Board opinion dated January 18, 1972 that sufficient cause for detention.
State Government confirmed order on February 1, 1972; reported to Central Government on February 3, 1972.

Petitioner's representation received by State Government on December 11, 1971; considered on January 14, 1972; delay due to refugee influx, Pakistan aggression, increase in detention cases from Naxalite activities.
Petitioner is 17 years old, studying in Xth class at Dhupguri High School; arrested on August 5, 1971 in connection with six cases; bailed out on November 10, 1971; re-arrested soon after.
Petitioner was absconding when detention order made.
Petitioner is staunch supporter of C.P.I.(ML) party and active member of its Action squad.

legal_issues.text: Whether Ground 1 (assault on Bulo Das Gupta) is vague and irrelevant to maintenance of public order, raising only law and order issue.
Whether detention order vitiated if one of two grounds is irrelevant and may have influenced detaining authority's subjective satisfaction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ground number 1 is vague, does not mention names/details of others, has no relevance to maintenance of public order; detention bad in law as impossible to say how far it influenced detaining authority.
Petitioner only 17 years old, Xth class student, previously arrested in six cases and bailed out.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner absconding when order made; staunch supporter of C.P.I.(ML) and active in Action squad; activities (assault and school arson) caused panic and disturbed public order, within S.3(1) and (2) of Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, S.3(1) and (2)

court_reasoning.text: Ground 1 refers only to solitary assault on individual (murderous assault on Bulo Das Gupta), no details on weapon, injuries, motive; equates to ordinary murder, raises law and order problem, not public order disturbance affecting community tempo.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between law and order (individual acts) and public order (community-wide impact), per Arun Ghosh and Ram Manohar Lohia.

court_reasoning.text: Ground 2 germane to public order, but with only two grounds, irrelevant Ground 1 not of unessential nature; its exclusion might reasonably affect detaining authority's subjective satisfaction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If some grounds invalid, cannot predicate authority's satisfaction without them; principles from Dwarka Das Bhatia, Ram Krishan Bhardwaj.

court_reasoning.text: Detention order vitiated; individual liberty cherished right under Constitution; authorities must act strictly per law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act encroaches on personal liberty; must comply strictly with limitations.

holdings.text: Ground 1 irrelevant to public order; its potential influence vitiates entire detention order.
Detention order struck down as outside statutory scope.

precedents_cited.case_name: Arun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between law/order and public order; degree of harm and community effect.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Public order embraces community; acts against individuals may not disturb public order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pushkar Mukherjee v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Stray acts against individuals not subversive of public order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shyamal Chakraborty v. Commissioner of Police, Calcutta
Nagendra Nath Mondal v. State of West Bengal
Dr. Ram Krishan Bhardwaj v. State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Grounds must not be vague; each ground must satisfy requirement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarka Das Bhatia v. State of Jammu & Kashmir
precedents_cited.relevance: Invalid grounds vitiate order if they might affect subjective satisfaction.
Principle on subjective satisfaction and invalid grounds.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rameshwar Lal v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Grounds must not be vague to enable representation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Motilal Jain v. State of Bihar

statutes_cited.name: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to detain to prevent prejudicial acts to public order; grounds supplied under Act.

outcome.summary: Impugned detention order quashed as Ground 1 irrelevant to public order and likely influenced detaining authority; petitioner directed to be released forthwith.

key_quotes.text: "Public order was said to embrace more of the community than law and order. Public order is the even tempo of the life of the community..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines distinction between law/order and public order from Ram Manohar Lohia.

key_quotes.text: "If some out of them are found to be non-existent or irrelevant, the Court cannot predicate what the subjective satisfaction of the said authority would have been..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle from Dwarka Das Bhatia on vitiation of detention orders.

key_quotes.text: "Individual liberty is a cherished right, one of the most valuable fundamental rights guaranteed by our Constitution..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
